events.text: January 8 – A Zairean cargo plane crashes into a crowded market in the center of the capital city of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Kinshasa, killing 300 people.
events.html: January 8 – A Zairean cargo plane crashes into a crowded market in the center of the capital city of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Kinshasa, killing 300 people.

events.text: January 9–20 – Serious fighting breaks out between Russian soldiers and rebel fighters in Chechnya.
events.html: January 9–20 – Serious fighting breaks out between Russian soldiers and rebel fighters in Chechnya.

events.text: January 11 – Ryutaro Hashimoto, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, becomes Prime Minister of Japan.
events.html: January 11 – Ryutaro Hashimoto, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, becomes Prime Minister of Japan.

events.text: January 13 – Italy's Prime Minister, Lamberto Dini, resigns after the failure of all-party talks to confirm him. New talks are initiated by President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro to form a new government.
events.html: January 13 – Italy's Prime Minister, Lamberto Dini, resigns after the failure of all-party talks to confirm him. New talks are initiated by President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro to form a new government.

events.text: January 14 – Jorge Sampaio is elected President of Portugal.
events.html: January 14 – Jorge Sampaio is elected President of Portugal.

events.text: January 16 – President of Sierra Leone Valentine Strasser is deposed by the chief of defence, Julius Maada Bio. Bio promises to restore power following elections scheduled for February.
events.html: January 16 – President of Sierra Leone Valentine Strasser is deposed by the chief of defence, Julius Maada Bio. Bio promises to restore power following elections scheduled for February.

events.text: January 18 – Michael Jackson files for divorce from Lisa Marie Presley.
events.html: January 18 – Michael Jackson files for divorce from Lisa Marie Presley.

events.text:
January 19
The North Cape oil spill occurs as an engine fire forces the tugboat Scandia ashore on Moonstone Beach in South Kingstown, Rhode Island. The North Cape Barge is pulled along with it and leaks 820,000 gallons of home heating oil.
An Indonesian ferry sinks off the northern tip of Sumatra, drowning more than 100 people.
events.html:
January 19
  • The North Cape oil spill occurs as an engine fire forces the tugboat Scandia ashore on Moonstone Beach in South Kingstown, Rhode Island. The North Cape Barge is pulled along with it and leaks 820,000 gallons of home heating oil.
  • An Indonesian ferry sinks off the northern tip of Sumatra, drowning more than 100 people.

events.text: An Indonesian ferry sinks off the northern tip of Sumatra, drowning more than 100 people.
events.html: An Indonesian ferry sinks off the northern tip of Sumatra, drowning more than 100 people.

events.text: January 20 – Yasser Arafat is re-elected president of the Palestinian Authority.
events.html: January 20 – Yasser Arafat is re-elected president of the Palestinian Authority.

events.text: January 21 – France undertakes its last nuclear weapons test.
events.html: January 21 – France undertakes its last nuclear weapons test.

events.text: January 22 – Andreas Papandreou, Prime Minister of Greece, resigns due to health problems; a new government forms under Costas Simitis.
events.html: January 22 – Andreas Papandreou, Prime Minister of Greece, resigns due to health problems; a new government forms under Costas Simitis.

events.text: January 24 – Polish Premier Józef Oleksy resigns amid charges that he spied for Moscow. He is replaced by Włodzimierz Cimoszewicz.
events.html: January 24 – Polish Premier Józef Oleksy resigns amid charges that he spied for Moscow. He is replaced by Włodzimierz Cimoszewicz.

events.text: January 27 – Colonel Ibrahim Baré Maïnassara deposes the first democratically elected President of Niger, Mahamane Ousmane, in a military coup.
events.html: January 27 – Colonel Ibrahim Baré Maïnassara deposes the first democratically elected President of Niger, Mahamane Ousmane, in a military coup.

events.text:
January 31
Colombo Central Bank bombing: an explosives-filled truck rams into the gates of the Central Bank in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing at least 86 people and injuring 1,400.
An amateur astronomer from southern Japan discovers Comet Hyakutake; it will pass very close to the Earth in March.
events.html:
January 31
  • Colombo Central Bank bombing: an explosives-filled truck rams into the gates of the Central Bank in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing at least 86 people and injuring 1,400.
  • An amateur astronomer from southern Japan discovers Comet Hyakutake; it will pass very close to the Earth in March.

events.text: February 3 – The 6.6 Mw  earthquake near Lijiang in South-west China kills up to 322 people, injures 17,000, and leaves 300,000 homeless.
events.html: February 3 – The 6.6 Mw  earthquake near Lijiang in South-west China kills up to 322 people, injures 17,000, and leaves 300,000 homeless.

events.text: February 6 – Birgenair Flight 301, on a charter flight from the Caribbean to Germany, crashes into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of the Dominican Republic, killing all 189 passengers and crew.
events.html: February 6 – Birgenair Flight 301, on a charter flight from the Caribbean to Germany, crashes into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of the Dominican Republic, killing all 189 passengers and crew.

events.text: February 7 – René Préval succeeds Jean-Bertrand Aristide as President of Haiti in the first peaceful handover of power since the nation achieved independence 192 years earlier, in 1804.
events.html: February 7 – René Préval succeeds Jean-Bertrand Aristide as President of Haiti in the first peaceful handover of power since the nation achieved independence 192 years earlier, in 1804.

events.text:
February 9
The element copernicium is created by fusing a 208Pb nucleus with a 70Zn nucleus, forming 278Cn. Given the placeholder name "ununbium", the element is not named until 2010.
An IRA ceasefire ends with the Docklands bombing in London's Canary Wharf District, killing two people and causing over £85,000,000 worth of damage.
Disney formally finalizes its $19 billion acquisition of the ABC parent, Capital Cities/ABC Inc.
events.html:

  • An IRA ceasefire ends with the Docklands bombing in London's Canary Wharf District, killing two people and causing over £85,000,000 worth of damage.
  • Disney formally finalizes its $19 billion acquisition of the ABC parent, Capital Cities/ABC Inc.

events.html: Disney formally finalizes its $19 billion acquisition of the ABC parent, Capital Cities/ABC Inc.

events.text: February 10 – Bosnian Serbs break off contact with the Bosnian government and with representatives of Ifor, the NATO localised force, in reaction to the arrest of several Bosnian Serb war criminals.
events.html: February 10 – Bosnian Serbs break off contact with the Bosnian government and with representatives of Ifor, the NATO localised force, in reaction to the arrest of several Bosnian Serb war criminals.

events.text: February 14 – Violent clashes erupt between Filipino soldiers and Vietnamese boat people, as the Filipino government attempts to forcibly repatriate hundreds of Vietnamese asylum seekers.
events.html: February 14 – Violent clashes erupt between Filipino soldiers and Vietnamese boat people, as the Filipino government attempts to forcibly repatriate hundreds of Vietnamese asylum seekers.

events.text:
February 15
The American Embassy in Athens, Greece, comes under mortar fire.
Begum Khaleda Zia is re-elected as Prime Minister of Bangladesh. The country's second democratic election is marred by low voter turnout, due to several boycotts and pre-election violence, which has resulted in at least thirteen deaths.
The UK government publishes the Scott Report.
events.html:
February 15
  • The American Embassy in Athens, Greece, comes under mortar fire.
  • Begum Khaleda Zia is re-elected as Prime Minister of Bangladesh. The country's second democratic election is marred by low voter turnout, due to several boycotts and pre-election violence, which has resulted in at least thirteen deaths.
  • The UK government publishes the Scott Report.

events.text: February 16 – 1996 Maryland train collision: A Chicago-bound Amtrak train, the Capitol Limited, collides with a MARC commuter train bound for Washington, D.C., killing 11 people.
events.html: February 16 – 1996 Maryland train collision: A Chicago-bound Amtrak train, the Capitol Limited, collides with a MARC commuter train bound for Washington, D.C., killing 11 people.

events.text: February 17 – The 8.2 Mw  Biak earthquake strikes the Papua province of eastern Indonesia with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe). A large tsunami followed, leaving 166 people dead or missing and 423 injured.
events.html: February 17 – The 8.2 Mw  Biak earthquake strikes the Papua province of eastern Indonesia with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe). A large tsunami followed, leaving 166 people dead or missing and 423 injured.

events.text: February 24 – Cuban fighter jets shoot down two American aircraft belonging to the Cuban exile group Brothers to the Rescue. Cuban officials assert that they invaded Cuban airspace.
events.html: February 24 – Cuban fighter jets shoot down two American aircraft belonging to the Cuban exile group Brothers to the Rescue. Cuban officials assert that they invaded Cuban airspace.

events.text: February 25 – Two suicide bombs in Israel kill 25 and injure 80; Hamas claims responsibility.
events.html: February 25 – Two suicide bombs in Israel kill 25 and injure 80; Hamas claims responsibility.

events.text:
February 29
Faucett Perú Flight 251 en route from Lima to Rodriguez Ballon airport crashes into a mountain near Arequipa; all 123 people on board are killed.
At least 81 people drown when a boat capsizes 120 kilometres east of Kampala, Uganda.
The Bosnian government declares the end of the Siege of Sarajevo.

February 29

  • At least 81 people drown when a boat capsizes 120 kilometres east of Kampala, Uganda.
  • The Bosnian government declares the end of the Siege of Sarajevo.

events.text: March 1 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraqi forces refuse UNSCOM inspection teams access to five sites designated for inspection. The teams enter the sites only after delays of up to seventeen hours.
events.html: March 1 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraqi forces refuse UNSCOM inspection teams access to five sites designated for inspection. The teams enter the sites only after delays of up to seventeen hours.

events.text: March 2 – 1996 Australian federal election: The Liberal/National Coalition led by John Howard defeats the Labor Government led by Prime Minister Paul Keating. Howard was sworn in on March 11.[1]
events.html: March 2 – 1996 Australian federal election: The Liberal/National Coalition led by John Howard defeats the Labor Government led by Prime Minister Paul Keating. Howard was sworn in on March 11.[1]

events.text: March 3 – José María Aznar, leader of the Popular Party, is elected as Prime Minister of Spain, replacing Felipe González.
events.html: March 3 – José María Aznar, leader of the Popular Party, is elected as Prime Minister of Spain, replacing Felipe González.

events.text: March 3–4 – Two suicide bombs explode in Israel, killing 32 people. The Yahya Ayyash Units admit responsibility, and Palestinian president Yasser Arafat condemns the killings in a televised address. Israel warns of retaliation.
events.html: March 3–4 – Two suicide bombs explode in Israel, killing 32 people. The Yahya Ayyash Units admit responsibility, and Palestinian president Yasser Arafat condemns the killings in a televised address. Israel warns of retaliation.

events.text:
March 6
Mesut Yılmaz of ANAP forms the new government of Turkey (53rd government).
A boat carrying market traders capsizes outside Freetown harbour in Sierra Leone, killing at least 86 people.
Chechen rebels attack the Russian government headquarters in Grozny; 70 Russian soldiers and policemen and 130 Chechen fighters are killed.
events.html:
March 6
  • Mesut Yılmaz of ANAP forms the new government of Turkey (53rd government).
  • A boat carrying market traders capsizes outside Freetown harbour in Sierra Leone, killing at least 86 people.
  • Chechen rebels attack the Russian government headquarters in Grozny; 70 Russian soldiers and policemen and 130 Chechen fighters are killed.

events.text: March 8 – China begins surface-to-surface missile testing and military exercises off Taiwanese coastal areas. The United States government condemns the act as provocation, and the Taiwanese government warns of retaliation.
events.html: March 8 – China begins surface-to-surface missile testing and military exercises off Taiwanese coastal areas. The United States government condemns the act as provocation, and the Taiwanese government warns of retaliation.

events.text: March 9 – Jorge Sampaio becomes the new Portuguese president.
events.html: March 9 – Jorge Sampaio becomes the new Portuguese president.

events.text: March 13 – Dunblane massacre: Unemployed former shopkeeper Thomas Hamilton walks into the Dunblane Primary School in Scotland and opens fire, killing sixteen infant school pupils and one teacher before committing suicide.
events.html: March 13 – Dunblane massacre: Unemployed former shopkeeper Thomas Hamilton walks into the Dunblane Primary School in Scotland and opens fire, killing sixteen infant school pupils and one teacher before committing suicide.

events.text: March 14 – An international peace summit is held in Egypt in response to escalating terrorist attacks in the Middle East.
events.html: March 14 – An international peace summit is held in Egypt in response to escalating terrorist attacks in the Middle East.

events.text: March 15 – Fokker, a major manufacturer of small size aircraft, goes bankrupt in Netherlands.[2]
events.html: March 15 – Fokker, a major manufacturer of small size aircraft, goes bankrupt in Netherlands.[2]

events.text: March 16 – Robert Mugabe is re-elected as President of Zimbabwe, although only 32% of the electorate actually voted.
events.html: March 16 – Robert Mugabe is re-elected as President of Zimbabwe, although only 32% of the electorate actually voted.

events.text: March 17 – Sri Lanka wins the Cricket World Cup by beating Australia in the final.
events.html: March 17 – Sri Lanka wins the Cricket World Cup by beating Australia in the final.

events.text: March 18 – The Ozone Disco Club fire in Quezon City, Philippines kills 163 people.
events.html: March 18 – The Ozone Disco Club fire in Quezon City, Philippines kills 163 people.

events.text: March 22 – Sweden's Finance Minister Göran Persson becomes the new Prime Minister of Sweden.
events.html: March 22 – Sweden's Finance Minister Göran Persson becomes the new Prime Minister of Sweden.

events.text: March 23 – Taiwan (Republic of China) holds its first direct elections for president; Lee Teng-hui is re-elected.
events.html: March 23 – Taiwan (Republic of China) holds its first direct elections for president; Lee Teng-hui is re-elected.

events.text: March 24 – The Marcopper mining disaster on the island of Marinduque, Philippines takes place.
events.html: March 24 – The Marcopper mining disaster on the island of Marinduque, Philippines takes place.

events.text: March 25 – The 68th Academy Awards, hosted by Whoopi Goldberg, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles with Braveheart winning Best Picture.
events.html: March 25 – The 68th Academy Awards, hosted by Whoopi Goldberg, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles with Braveheart winning Best Picture.

events.text: March 26 – The International Monetary Fund approves a $10.2 billion loan to Russia for economic reform.
events.html: March 26 – The International Monetary Fund approves a $10.2 billion loan to Russia for economic reform.

events.text: April 1 – The Halifax Regional Municipality in Nova Scotia is created.
events.html: April 1 – The Halifax Regional Municipality in Nova Scotia is created.

events.text:
April 3
A Boeing 737 military jet crashes into a mountain north of Dubrovnik, Croatia. All 35 people on board are killed, including United States Secretary of Commerce Ron Brown.
Massacres of Hutus by Tutsis in Burundi take place with more than 450 killed within a few days.
The FBI arrested Theodore Kaczynski, the suspected Unabomber at his cabin in Lincoln, Montana.

April 3

  • Massacres of Hutus by Tutsis in Burundi take place with more than 450 killed within a few days.
  • The FBI arrested Theodore Kaczynski, the suspected Unabomber at his cabin in Lincoln, Montana.

events.text:
April 6
Fighting breaks out in Monrovia, Liberia, between various rebel factions struggling for power in the country's interrupted civil war. Several foreign nationals leave the nation.
Turkish authorities begin Operation Hawk, a military offensive against rebels from the Kurdistan Workers' Party in south-east Turkey.

events.text: April 9 – In a common statement, the European Union officially recognises the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
events.html: April 9 – In a common statement, the European Union officially recognises the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.

events.text: April 11 – The Israeli government launches Operation Grapes of Wrath, consisting of massive attacks on Lebanon, in retaliation for "terrorist attacks", and sparking off a violent series of retaliations.
events.html: April 11 – The Israeli government launches Operation Grapes of Wrath, consisting of massive attacks on Lebanon, in retaliation for "terrorist attacks", and sparking off a violent series of retaliations.

events.text: April 13 – 2 women and 4 children are killed after Israeli helicopter stroke an ambulance in Mansouri, Lebanon.
events.html: April 13 – 2 women and 4 children are killed after Israeli helicopter stroke an ambulance in Mansouri, Lebanon.

events.text: April 16 – Israel strikes a civilian house in Nabatieh Fawka, Lebanon, killing 9 people, including 7 children.
events.html: April 16 – Israel strikes a civilian house in Nabatieh Fawka, Lebanon, killing 9 people, including 7 children.

events.text:
April 18
Qana Massacre: Over 100 Lebanese civilians are killed after Israel shells the United Nations compound in Qana.
In reaction to the Qana Massacre, an Islamist group in Egypt open fire on a hotel, killing eighteen Greek tourists and injuring seventeen others.
Two days before the NFL draft, Nebraska Quarterback Brook Berringer is killed when the plane he is piloting crashes in an alfalfa field. During the 1996 NFL draft, the league held a moment of silence for Berringer, who was expected to be selected by the Denver Broncos.

events.text: April 18-19 – Two consecutive tornados hit Decatur, Illinois, causing approximately $10.5 million in damage. The April 19 Tornado also hit Urbana and Ogden
events.html: April 18-19 – Two consecutive tornados hit Decatur, Illinois, causing approximately $10.5 million in damage. The April 19 Tornado also hit Urbana and Ogden

events.text: April 21 – A general election in Italy proclaims a new center-left government headed by Romano Prodi, replacing Silvio Berlusconi.
events.html: April 21 – A general election in Italy proclaims a new center-left government headed by Romano Prodi, replacing Silvio Berlusconi.

events.text: April 22 – General Lino Oviedo is fired of his role as commander of the army by the president Juan Carlos Wasmosy. After this, he tries to orchestrate a Coup d'état, but he fails because the president was not willing to resign.
events.html: April 22 – General Lino Oviedo is fired of his role as commander of the army by the president Juan Carlos Wasmosy. After this, he tries to orchestrate a Coup d'état, but he fails because the president was not willing to resign.

events.text: April 24 – At the urging of Yasser Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization drops its clause calling for the removal of Israel. The Israeli government responds by dropping a similar clause concerning the existence of Palestine.
events.html: April 24 – At the urging of Yasser Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization drops its clause calling for the removal of Israel. The Israeli government responds by dropping a similar clause concerning the existence of Palestine.

events.text:
April 28
Port Arthur massacre: Martin Bryant kills 35 people at the Port Arthur tourist site in Tasmania, Australia.
A bomb explodes in Bhaiperu, Pakistan, killing more than 60 people.
events.html:
April 28
  • Port Arthur massacre: Martin Bryant kills 35 people at the Port Arthur tourist site in Tasmania, Australia.
  • A bomb explodes in Bhaiperu, Pakistan, killing more than 60 people.

events.text: May – Iraq disarmament crisis: UNSCOM supervises the destruction of Al-Hakam, Iraq's main production facility of biological warfare agents.
events.html: May – Iraq disarmament crisis: UNSCOM supervises the destruction of Al-Hakam, Iraq's main production facility of biological warfare agents.

events.text:
May 9
South Africa's National Party pulls out of the coalition government formed two years earlier, and the African National Congress assumes full political control.
Ugandan president Yoweri Museveni wins a landslide victory in the country's first direct presidential elections, securing 75% of the vote.
events.html:
May 9
  • South Africa's National Party pulls out of the coalition government formed two years earlier, and the African National Congress assumes full political control.
  • Ugandan president Yoweri Museveni wins a landslide victory in the country's first direct presidential elections, securing 75% of the vote.

events.html: Ugandan president Yoweri Museveni wins a landslide victory in the country's first direct presidential elections, securing 75% of the vote.

events.text:
May 10
1996 Everest disaster: A sudden storm engulfs Mount Everest with several climbing teams high on the mountain, leaving eight people dead. By the end of the month, at least four other climbers die in the worst season of fatalities on the mountain to date.
The Australian government introduces a nationwide ban on the private possession of both automatic and semi-automatic rifles, in response to the Port Arthur massacre.

events.text: May 11 – After takeoff from Miami, a fire started by improperly handled oxygen canisters in the cargo hold of Atlanta-bound ValuJet Flight 592 causes the Douglas DC-9 to crash in the Florida Everglades, killing all 110 people on board.
events.html: May 11 – After takeoff from Miami, a fire started by improperly handled oxygen canisters in the cargo hold of Atlanta-bound ValuJet Flight 592 causes the Douglas DC-9 to crash in the Florida Everglades, killing all 110 people on board.

events.text: May 13 – Severe thunderstorms and a tornado in Bangladesh kill 600 people.
events.html: May 13 – Severe thunderstorms and a tornado in Bangladesh kill 600 people.

events.text: May 17–28 – Atal Bihari Vajpayee, leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party, is elected as Prime Minister of India, replacing P. V. Narasimha Rao of the Indian National Congress. However, the party does not receive an overall majority and Vajpayee resigns thirteen days later rather than face a no confidence vote and is replaced by the United Front leader, Deve Gowda.
events.html: May 17–28 – Atal Bihari Vajpayee, leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party, is elected as Prime Minister of India, replacing P. V. Narasimha Rao of the Indian National Congress. However, the party does not receive an overall majority and Vajpayee resigns thirteen days later rather than face a no confidence vote and is replaced by the United Front leader, Deve Gowda.

events.text: May 18 – The X Prize Foundation launches the $10,000,000 Ansari X Prize.
events.html: May 18 – The X Prize Foundation launches the $10,000,000 Ansari X Prize.

events.text:
May 21
The MV Bukoba sinks in Tanzanian waters in Lake Victoria, killing nearly 1,000 people in one of Africa's worst maritime disasters.
The Trappist Martyrs of Atlas are executed.

May 21

events.text: May 23 – Members of the Armed Islamic Group in Algeria kill seven French Trappist monks, after talks with French government concerning the imprisonment of several GIA sympathisers break down.
events.html: May 23 – Members of the Armed Islamic Group in Algeria kill seven French Trappist monks, after talks with French government concerning the imprisonment of several GIA sympathisers break down.

events.text: May 27 – First Chechnya War: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with Chechnyan rebels for the first time and negotiates a ceasefire for the dispute.
events.html: May 27 – First Chechnya War: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with Chechnyan rebels for the first time and negotiates a ceasefire for the dispute.

events.text: May 28 – Albania's general election of May 26 is declared unfair by international monitors, and the ruling Democratic Party under President Muhannad Ibrahim is charged by the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe with rigging the elections. Several hundred protestors gather in Tirana to demonstrate against the election result.

events.text: May 30 – The Likud Party, led by Benjamin Netanyahu, wins a narrow victory in the Israeli general election.
events.html: May 30 – The Likud Party, led by Benjamin Netanyahu, wins a narrow victory in the Israeli general election.

events.text: June – Iraq disarmament crisis: As Iraq continues to refuse inspectors access to a number of sites, the United States fails in its attempt to build support for military action against Iraq in the UN Security Council.
events.html: June – Iraq disarmament crisis: As Iraq continues to refuse inspectors access to a number of sites, the United States fails in its attempt to build support for military action against Iraq in the UN Security Council.

events.text: June 1–3 – The Czech Republic's first general election ends inconclusively. Prime Minister Václav Klaus and his incumbent Civic Democratic Party emerge as the winners, but are unable to form a majority government. President Václav Havel refuses to invite Klaus to form a coalition.
events.html: June 1–3 – The Czech Republic's first general election ends inconclusively. Prime Minister Václav Klaus and his incumbent Civic Democratic Party emerge as the winners, but are unable to form a majority government. President Václav Havel refuses to invite Klaus to form a coalition.

events.text: June 4 – The space rocket Ariane 5 explodes forty seconds after takeoff in French Guiana. The project costs European governments $7,500,000,000 over eleven years.
events.html: June 4 – The space rocket Ariane 5 explodes forty seconds after takeoff in French Guiana. The project costs European governments $7,500,000,000 over eleven years.

events.text: June 6 – Leighton W. Smith, Jr. resigns as NATO commander in the face of increasing criticism.
events.html: June 6 – Leighton W. Smith, Jr. resigns as NATO commander in the face of increasing criticism.

events.text: June 8–30 – England hosts the UEFA Euro 1996 football tournament, which is won by Germany.
events.html: June 8–30 – England hosts the UEFA Euro 1996 football tournament, which is won by Germany.

events.text:
June 11
An explosion in a São Paulo suburban shopping centre kills 44 people and injures more than 100.
A peace convoy carrying Chechen separatist leaders and international diplomats is targeted by a series of remotely controlled land mines; eight people are killed.

June 11

A new government is formed in Turkey, with Necmettin Erbakan of Refah Partisi becoming Prime Minister of the coalition government, and Deputy/Foreign Minister Tansu Çiller of the True Path Party succeeding him after two years.
The Constitution of Ukraine is signed into law.

The Prince's Trust concert is held in Hyde Park, London, and is attended by 150,000 people. The Who headlines the event in their first performance since 1989.

events.text: July 12 – Hurricane Bertha: made landfall in North Carolina as a Category 2 storm, causing $270 million in damage ($446 million in present-day terms[4]) to the United States and its possessions and many indirect deaths.
events.html: July 12 – Hurricane Bertha: made landfall in North Carolina as a Category 2 storm, causing $270 million in damage ($446 million in present-day terms[4]) to the United States and its possessions and many indirect deaths.

events.text: July 16 – An outbreak of E. coli food poisoning in Japan results in 6,000 children being ill, including two deaths, after a group of school children eat contaminated lunches.

The Community of Portuguese Language Countries (Comunidade dos Países de Língua Portuguesa) is constituted.
Paris- and Rome-bound TWA Flight 800 (Boeing 747) explodes off the coast of Long Island, New York, killing all 230 people on board.

The 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, United States, begin.
Bosnian Serb President Radovan Karadžić resigns from public office in Republika Srpska after being indicted for war crimes.

events.text: July 24 – The Dehiwala train bombing kills 56 commuters outside Colombo.
events.html: July 24 – The Dehiwala train bombing kills 56 commuters outside Colombo.

events.text: July 25 – The Tutsi-led Burundian army performs a coup and reinstalls previous president Pierre Buyoya, ousting current president Sylvestre Ntibantunganya.
events.html: July 25 – The Tutsi-led Burundian army performs a coup and reinstalls previous president Pierre Buyoya, ousting current president Sylvestre Ntibantunganya.

events.text:
July 27
The Centennial Olympic Park bombing at the 1996 Summer Olympics kills one person and injures 111.
Indonesian government forces attacked the head office of the Indonesian Democratic Party, which was being occupied by supporters of recently ousted party leader Megawati Sukarnoputri.
Australian serial killer Ivan Milat is sentenced to life in prison for carrying out the Backpacker murders of 1989–93. He remains at the Long Bay Correctional Centre until his death in 2019.

events.text: August 7 – Heavy rains kill more than 80 campers near Huesca, Spain.
events.html: August 7 – Heavy rains kill more than 80 campers near Huesca, Spain.

events.text: August 11 – Oasis headlines the biggest free-standing concert in UK history in two nights (Aug 10th & 11th) at Knebworth, Hertfordshire.
events.html: August 11 – Oasis headlines the biggest free-standing concert in UK history in two nights (Aug 10th & 11th) at Knebworth, Hertfordshire.

events.text: August 13 – Data sent back by the Galileo space probe indicates there may be water on one of Jupiter's moons.
events.html: August 13 – Data sent back by the Galileo space probe indicates there may be water on one of Jupiter's moons.

events.text: August 14 – A rocket ignited during a fireworks display in Arequipa, Peru knocks down a high-tension power cable into a dense crowd, electrocuting 35 people.
events.html: August 14 – A rocket ignited during a fireworks display in Arequipa, Peru knocks down a high-tension power cable into a dense crowd, electrocuting 35 people.

events.text: August 15 – Bob Dole is nominated for President of the United States, and Jack Kemp for vice president, at the Republican National Convention in San Diego, California.
events.html: August 15 – Bob Dole is nominated for President of the United States, and Jack Kemp for vice president, at the Republican National Convention in San Diego, California.

events.text: August 16 – Brookfield Zoo, Chicago. After a 3-year-old boy falls into the 20-foot (6.1 m) deep gorilla enclosure, Binti Jua, a female lowland gorilla sits with the injured boy until his rescue.
events.html: August 16 – Brookfield Zoo, Chicago. After a 3-year-old boy falls into the 20-foot (6.1 m) deep gorilla enclosure, Binti Jua, a female lowland gorilla sits with the injured boy until his rescue.

events.text:
August 21
Former State President of South Africa, F. W. de Klerk, makes an official apology for crimes committed under Apartheid to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in Cape Town.
In the UK, Queen Elizabeth II issues letters patent on divorced former wives of British princes, taking away from the ex-wives the attribute and style of Royal Highness. With that Sarah, Duchess of York as well as Diana, Princess of Wales legally cease to be Royals, but they remain as non-royal Duchess and Princess.

events.html: September 4 – The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia attack a military base in Guaviare, Colombia, starting three weeks of guerrilla warfare that will claim the lives of at least 130 Colombians.

events.text: September 5 – Hurricane Fran makes landfall near Cape Fear, North Carolina as a Category 3 storm with 115 mph (185 km/h) sustained winds. Fran caused over $3 billion in damages ($4.95 billion in present-day terms[4]) and killed 27 people, mainly in North Carolina. The name "Fran" was retired due to the extensive damage.

events.text: September 10 – Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) signed (it will be ratified 180 days after ratification by 44 Annex 2 countries).

Alija Izetbegović is elected President of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the country's first election since the Bosnian War.
Rapper and actor Tupac Shakur dies at the age of 25, six days after being shot and mortally wounded in Las Vegas.

events.html: Aeroperú Flight 603 crashes into the Pacific Ocean when the instruments fail just after takeoff from Lima Airport, killing all 70 people on board.

events.text: October 6 – The government of New Zealand agrees to pay $130 million worth of compensation for the loss of land suffered by the Māori population between the years of 1844 and 1864.
events.html: October 6 – The government of New Zealand agrees to pay $130 million worth of compensation for the loss of land suffered by the Māori population between the years of 1844 and 1864.

events.text: October 10 – Time Warner completes its million-dollar acquisition of the Turner Broadcasting System.
events.html: October 10 – Time Warner completes its million-dollar acquisition of the Turner Broadcasting System.

events.text: October 22 – A fire at La Planta prison in southwest Caracas, Venezuela, kills thirty prisoners.
events.html: October 22 – A fire at La Planta prison in southwest Caracas, Venezuela, kills thirty prisoners.

events.text: October 30 – Fighting erupts when Banyamulenga Tutsis of Laurent Kabila in Zaire seize Uvira and proceed to kill Hutu refugees.
events.html: October 30 – Fighting erupts when Banyamulenga Tutsis of Laurent Kabila in Zaire seize Uvira and proceed to kill Hutu refugees.

events.text: October 31 – TAM Transportes Aéreos Regionais Flight 402 crashes into a densely populated area of São Paulo, killing all 96 people on board.
events.html: October 31 – TAM Transportes Aéreos Regionais Flight 402 crashes into a densely populated area of São Paulo, killing all 96 people on board.

events.text: November – Iraq disarmament crisis: UNSCOM inspectors uncover buried prohibited missile parts. Iraq refuses to allow UNSCOM teams to remove remnants of missile engines for analysis outside of the country.
events.html: November – Iraq disarmament crisis: UNSCOM inspectors uncover buried prohibited missile parts. Iraq refuses to allow UNSCOM teams to remove remnants of missile engines for analysis outside of the country.

events.text:
November 5
1996 United States presidential election: Incumbent Democratic President Bill Clinton defeats his Republican challenger, Bob Dole.
Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government is dismissed by President Farooq Leghari after widespread allegations of corruption.
events.html:
November 5
  • 1996 United States presidential election: Incumbent Democratic President Bill Clinton defeats his Republican challenger, Bob Dole.
  • Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government is dismissed by President Farooq Leghari after widespread allegations of corruption.

events.text:
November 7
A category 4 cyclone strikes Andhra Pradesh, India, killing at least 1,000 people.
NASA launches the Mars Global Surveyor.

events.text: November 8 – All 144 people on board a Nigerian-owned Boeing 727 die after the aircraft crashed into the Atlantic Ocean while approaching Lagos airport.
events.html: November 8 – All 144 people on board a Nigerian-owned Boeing 727 die after the aircraft crashed into the Atlantic Ocean while approaching Lagos airport.

events.text: November 12 – Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 collides in mid-air with Kazakhstan Airlines Il-76 in New Delhi, India, resulting in the loss of 349 lives.
events.html: November 12 – Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 collides in mid-air with Kazakhstan Airlines Il-76 in New Delhi, India, resulting in the loss of 349 lives.

events.text:
November 17
A bomb explodes in Kaspiysk, Russia, killing 32 people.
Emil Constantinescu is elected as President of Romania.

  • Emil Constantinescu is elected as President of Romania.

events.text: November 18 – Frederick Chiluba is re-elected as President of Zambia.
events.html: November 18 – Frederick Chiluba is re-elected as President of Zambia.

events.text:
November 19
Martin Bryant is sentenced to 35 consecutive sentences of life imprisonment plus 1,035 years without parole for murdering 35 people in a shooting spree in Tasmania earlier this year.
Preparatory Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Organization (CTBTO) established.
STS-80: Space Shuttle Columbia conducts the longest mission of the Space Shuttle program.

events.text: November 20 – The 1996 Garley Building fire occurred in Hong Kong, resulting in 41 deaths and 81 injuries.
events.html: November 20 – The 1996 Garley Building fire occurred in Hong Kong, resulting in 41 deaths and 81 injuries.

events.text: November 21 – A propane explosion at the Humberto Vidal shoe store and office building in San Juan, Puerto Rico kills 33 people.
events.html: November 21 – A propane explosion at the Humberto Vidal shoe store and office building in San Juan, Puerto Rico kills 33 people.

events.text:
November 23
The Republic of Angola officially joins the World Trade Organization as Angola.
Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961 is hijacked, then crashes into the Indian Ocean off the coast of Comoros after running out of fuel, killing 125.
Tamagotchi is released in Japan by Bandai.

  • Tamagotchi is released in Japan by Bandai.

events.text: December 9 – Jerry Rawlings is re-elected as President of Ghana.
events.html: December 9 – Jerry Rawlings is re-elected as President of Ghana.

events.text: December 11 – Tung Chee-hwa is appointed to become the new leader of Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese rule on July 1, 1997, at the end a 99-year lease to the United Kingdom.
events.html: December 11 – Tung Chee-hwa is appointed to become the new leader of Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese rule on July 1, 1997, at the end a 99-year lease to the United Kingdom.

events.text: December 13 – Ghanaian diplomat Kofi Annan is elected by the United Nations Security Council the next Secretary-General of the United Nations.
events.html: December 13 – Ghanaian diplomat Kofi Annan is elected by the United Nations Security Council the next Secretary-General of the United Nations.

events.text: December 17 – The Túpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement takes 72 hostages in the Japanese Embassy in Lima, Peru.
events.html: December 17 – The Túpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement takes 72 hostages in the Japanese Embassy in Lima, Peru.

events.text: December 25 – At least 283 migrants drown in the sinking of F174 near Capo Passero (Sicily).
events.html: December 25 – At least 283 migrants drown in the sinking of F174 near Capo Passero (Sicily).

December 26
The largest strike in South Korean history begins.
Six-year-old JonBenét Ramsey is found beaten and strangled in the basement of her family's home in Boulder, Colorado.
